Sources of stimuli and sensors

Stimulus class

class Sandbox_V1_4.Stimulus(x: float = None, y: float = None, theta: float = None, is_on: bool = True)[source]

An abstract class to represent a source of sensory stimulation.

__init__(x: float = None, y: float = None, theta: float = None, is_on: bool = True)[source]
Parameters:

  • x (float) – The x-coordinate of the stimulus. Defaults to None.

  • y (float) – The y-coordinate of the stimulus. Defaults to None.

  • theta (float) – The angular orientation of the stimulus. Defaults to None.

  • is_on (bool) – A flag which can be use to determine whether or not a stimulus can be detected. Defaults to True. This allows for the stimulus to be turned on and off, but the actual response to the state of this flag is determined elsewhere, e.g. in LightSource. Also, a sensor implementation could choose to ignore this flag and detect a stimulus even when it is not on.

get_data() → dict[source]

A method to return the data of the stimulus. Note: this is not likely to be particularly useful, as it only contains the original state, as recorded by System, and the current state of “is_on”.

Returns:

A dict containing the data returned from Sandbox.System.get_data(), plus is_on.

Return type:

dict

get_distance(x: float, y: float) → float[source]

A method for finding the Euclidean distance from the passed in x- and y-coordinates to the position of this stimulus, assuming it has position - this method should not be invoked on an instance of Stimulus which does not have position.

The passed in x- and y- coordinates can be used to get the distance from any position, but they will typically be the coordinates of a sensor which will potentially detect this stimulus.

Parameters:

  • x (float) – The x-component of the position to find the distance from.

  • y (float) – The y-component of the position to find the distance from.

Returns:

The distance.

Return type:

float

reset() → None[source]

A method to reset the Stimulus to its original state.

LightSource class

class Sandbox_V1_4.LightSource(x: float, y: float, theta: float = 0, spread=6.283185307179586, brightness: float = 1, gradient: float = 0.01, model: str = 'inv_sq', is_on: bool = True, colour: str = 'yellow', label: str = None)[source]

A subclass of Stimulus, LightSource is a class which represents a light source. It is possible to set the “model” of intensity of a LightSource to be either an inverse square law of decay with distance, or a linear one, or for the light to be detected with constant brightness at all distances.

__init__(x: float = None, y: float = None, theta: float = None, is_on: bool = True)[source]
Parameters:

  • x (float) – The x-coordinate of the light.

  • y (float) – The y-coordinate of the light.

  • theta (float) – The orientation of the light.

  • spread – The angular spread of light around theta. Can be used to create lights which are only detectable from certain angles. WARNING: this feature has not been used or tested in a long while, and is not guaranteed to work with this new Sandbox version.

  • brightness (float) – The brightness of the light, at its own coordinate.

  • gradient (float) – The gradient of brightness decay with distance, when the linear model is used.

  • model (str) – The light decay model. inv_sq, linear, and binary are valid models.

  • is_on (bool) – A flag which can be use to determine whether or not a light can be detected. Defaults to True. This allows for the light to be turned on and off.

  • colour (str) – The colour of the light. Note: this is for drawing only - no system currently implemented in Sandbox can detect a light’s RGB colour.

  • label (str) – A light source’s label defines a group. Any LightSensor with the same label attribute will detect all, and only, light sources which are in its list and also in that group. A LightSensor with no label will detect any LightSource in its list, regardless of label.

draw(ax) → None[source]

A method to draw the light source in the specified matplotlib axes. A LightSource which is switched on is drawn as a circle with colour specified by the light source’s colour attribute, with a smaller circle in its center which is orange coloured. A LightSource which is not on will have its outer circle coloured in grey.

Parameters:

ax (Matplotlib axes.) – The Matplotlib axes to draw the light on.

get_brightness_at(x: float, y: float, sensor_angle=None) → float[source]

A method to get the brightness of the light (as it is perceived) at the given xy coordinates, according to the light source’s model, and which angles it can be perceived from (determined by the light’s spread attribute).

Parameters:

  • x (float) – The x-component of the position to find the brightness at.

  • y (float) – The y-component of the position to find the brightness at.

  • sensor_angle (float) – The orientation of the sensor at the position to find the brightness at. For lights which are not omni-directional, this will affect whether the sensor can detect the light.

Returns:

The perceived brightness at the given coordinates.

Return type:

float

get_data() → dict[source]

Get the LightSource’s data. This method, if used, relies on the assumption that the LightSource and its properties are static.

Returns:

The LightSource’s data in dict form.

Return type:

dict

inv_sq_model(dist: float) → float[source]

A method to find the perceived brightness of the light source at the given distance, when the inverse square decay model is used.

Parameters:

dist (float) – The distance from the light source.

Returns:

The perceived brightness.

Return type:

float

linear_model(dist: float) → float[source]

A method to find the perceived brightness of the light source at the given distance, when the linear decay model is used.

Parameters:

dist (float) – The distance from the light source.

Returns:

The perceived brightness.

Return type:

float

pygame_draw(screen, scale: float, shiftx: float, shifty: float) → None[source]

A method to draw the light source in the specified PyGame display. A LightSource which is switched on is drawn as a circle with colour specified by the light source’s colour attribute, with a smaller circle in its center which is orange coloured. A LightSource which is not on will have its outer circle coloured in grey.

Parameters:

  • screen (PyGame display) – The PyGame display to draw on.

  • scale (float) – The scale to draw at.

  • shiftx (float) – The offset from centre in the x-axis for drawing.

  • shifty (float) – The offset from centre in the y-axis for drawing.

reset() → None[source]

A method to reset the LightSource to its original state.

PheromoneSource class

class Sandbox_V1_4.PheromoneSource(x, y, brightness=1, gradient=0.01, model='inv_sq', is_on=True)[source]

A class to represent a deposit of pheromones on the ground. The PheromoneSource extends LightSource, so pheromones can be detected with ordinary light sensors.

__init__(self, x, y, brightness=1, gradient=0.01, model='inv_sq', is_on=True)[source]
Parameters:

  • x (float) – The x-coordinate of the pheromone. Defaults to None.

  • y (float) – The y-coordinate of the pheromone. Defaults to None.

  • brightness (float) – The brightness of the light, at its own coordinate (but this will be multiplied by the pheromone’s concentration).

  • gradient (float) – The gradient of brightness decay with distance, when the linear model is used.

  • model (str) – The light decay model. inv_sq, linear, and binary are valid models.

  • is_on (bool) – A flag which can be use to determine whether or not a pheromone can be detected. Defaults to True. This allows for the pheromone to be turned on and off.

draw(ax)[source]

A method to draw the pheromone in the specified matplotlib axes. The concentration of pheromones is used to set the opacity of the pheromone.

Parameters:

ax (Matplotlib axes.) – The Matplotlib axes to draw the light on.

get_brightness_at(x, y, theta)[source]

A method to get the concentration of the pheromone (or brightness of light, as it is perceived) at the given xy coordinates, according to the light source’s model, and which angles it can be perceived from (determined by the light’s spread attribute).

Parameters:

  • x (float) – The x-component of the position to find the brightness at.

  • y (float) – The y-component of the position to find the brightness at.

  • theta (float) – The orientation of the sensor at the position to find the brightness at. For lights which are not omni-directional, this will affect whether the sensor can detect the light.

Returns:

The perceived brightness at the given coordinates, which is the light brightness multiplied by the pheromone concentration (quantity).

Return type:

float

pygame_draw(screen, scale, shiftx, shifty)[source]

A method to draw the pheromone in the specified PyGame display. A PheromoneSource is drawn as a circle with colour specified by the light source’s colour attribute, multiplied by its pheromone concentration.

Parameters:

  • screen (PyGame display) – The PyGame display to draw on.

  • scale (float) – The scale to draw at.

  • shiftx (float) – The offset from centre in the x-axis for drawing.

  • shifty (float) – The offset from centre in the y-axis for drawing.

Sensor class

class Sandbox_V1_4.Sensor(x: float = None, y: float = None, theta: float = None, colour: str = 'red', radius: float = 0.2, enabled: bool = True, name_str: str = 'Sensor', delay_steps: int = 0, noisemaker=None)[source]

An abstract class for representing sensors. The output from a Sensor can be both noisy and delayed, due to the incorporation of a NoiseSource and a DelayBlock.

__init__(self, x: float = None, y: float = None, theta: float = None, colour: str = 'red', radius: float = 0.2, enabled: bool = True, name_str: str = 'Sensor', delay_steps: int = 0, noisemaker=None)[source]
Parameters:

  • x (float) – The initial x-coordinate of the Sensor, defaults to None.

  • y (float) – The initial y-coordinate of the Sensor, defaults to None.

  • theta (float) – The initial angular orientation of the Sensor, defaults to None.

  • colour (str) – The colour of the sensor, for drawing.

  • radius (float) – The radius of the sensor, for drawing.

  • enabled (bool) – A flag for specifying whether or not a sensor is enabled. Only the attribute is implemented here - how to use it is a decision for subclasses, e.g. in LightSensor.

  • name_str (str) – The name of the sensor, used in plotting simulation data.

  • delay_steps (int) – The number of simulation steps a sensor signal will be delayed for.

  • noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The source of noise for this sensor. Defaults to None.

draw(ax) → None[source]

A method to draw the sensor in the specified matplotlib axes, as a small coloured circle.

Parameters:

ax (Matplotlib axes) – The Matplotlib axes to draw the sensor on.

get_data() → Dict[str, float | List[float] | str][source]

A method to get the sensors data, in the form of a dict.

Returns:

The sensor’s data, which includes the data returned from Sandbox.System.get_data(), as well as the sensor’s colour and radius (which are both assumed to be static), and its “enabled” state and “name_str” string.

Return type:

dict

pygame_draw(screen, scale: float, shiftx: float, shifty: float) → None[source]

A method to draw the sensor in the specified PyGame display, as a small coloured circle.

Parameters:

  • screen (PyGame display) – The PyGame display to draw on.

  • scale (float) – The scale to draw at.

  • shiftx (float) – The offset from centre in the x-axis for drawing.

  • shifty (float) – The offset from centre in the y-axis for drawing.

reset() → None[source]

A method to reset a sensor to its initial state, so it can be reused in later simulations.

update(dt) → float[source]

A method to implement the addition of noise and a delay to a sensor’s dynamics, as well as keep a record of the sensor’s output.

All subclasses of Sensor must call this method from the end of their step() methods (I’m not happy with this design, and it will be changed in later implementations).

DelayBlock class

class Sandbox_V1_4.DelayBlock(delay_n: int)[source]

A class which implements a delay to a signal, currently only used in Sensor classes. The class uses a buffer to store delayed signal values.

__init__(self, delay_n: int)[source]
Parameters:

delay_n (int) – the number of simulation steps a signal will be delayed for.

step(input)[source]

Step the delayed signal forwards. Every time the delay block is stepped, the new input is placed in the buffer, and the oldest one is returned as the delayed value.

Parameters:

input (any) – The current signal value

Returns:

The delayed signal value

Return type:

any

LightSensor class

class Sandbox_V1_4.LightSensor(light_sources: List[LightSource], x: float, y: float, theta: float = 0, FOV: float = 6.283185307179586, noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, label: str = None, enabled: bool = True, name_str: str = 'LightSensor', colour: str = 'red', delay_steps: int = 0)[source]

A class which represents a light sensor. LightSensor inherits both from Sensor and FOV_thing.

__init__(self, light_sources: List[LightSource], x: float, y: float, theta: float = 0, FOV: float = 2 * math.pi, noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, label: str = None, enabled: bool = True, name_str: str = 'LightSensor', colour: str = 'red', delay_steps: int = 0)[source]
Parameters:

  • light_sources (list[Light_Source]) – The list of instances of LightSource which this sensor can potentially detect.

  • x (float) – The initial x-coordinate of the LightSensor, defaults to None.

  • y (float) – The initial y-coordinate of the LightSensor, defaults to None.

  • theta (float) – The initial angular orientation of the LightSensor, defaults to None.

  • FOV (float) – The sensor’s angular field of view. Defaults to 2pi.

  • noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The sensor’s source of noise.

  • label (str) – A LightSensor’s label determines which of the LightSource s in its list it can actually detect. Defaults to None, in which case the sensor will detect all light sources in its list. If a sensor’s label attribute is set to some string, then it will only detect light sources which have their label attributes set to the same value.

  • enabled (bool) – A flag for specifying whether or not a light sensor is enabled. Defaults to True. If set to False, then the sensor will not detect anything.

  • name_str (str) – The name of the sensor, used in plotting simulation data.

  • delay_steps (int) – The number of simulation steps a sensor signal will be delayed for.

clone()[source]

A method to clone a LightSensor. I’m not sure why I wrote this method - it is not used anywhere.

Returns:

A copy of the sensor.

Return type:

LightSensor

get_data() → dict[source]

A function to get the data from a LightSensor, in the form of a string-keyed dict.

These data, as and when they are included in the returned dict, can be accessed with the following keys:

  • data inherited from Sensor: see Sensor

  • current sensor output (activation): data["activation"]

  • history of sensor outputs (activations): data["activations"]

  • sensor’s field of view: data["FOV"]

  • label of light sources which this sensor will detect, if they are also in its list of light sources: data["label"]. If this value is None, then the sensor will detect lights with any label.

  • list of light sources that the sensor will detect, if they have the same label as it, or its label is None: data["light_sources"]

  • data of sensor’s noise source, if it has one: data["noises"]

Returns:

The sensors’s data.

Return type:

dict

pygame_draw(screen, scale: float, shiftx: float, shifty: float) → None[source]

A method for drawing the sensor, as a small circle with lines radiating out from its centre to inidicate the sensor’s FOV.

Parameters:

  • screen (PyGame display) – The PyGame display to draw on.

  • scale (float) – The scale to draw at.

  • shiftx (float) – The offset from centre in the x-axis for drawing.

  • shifty (float) – The offset from centre in the y-axis for drawing.

reset() → None[source]

A method to reset a sensor to its initial state, by resetting its x, y, theta, light_sources, activation, activations, label, enabled, and FOV attributes to their values at time of construction. If the sensor has a noisemaker, then the reset method of that object will also be called.

Note: this method will not reset any attributes which have been added outside of the Sandbox.LightSensor.__init__() method.

step(dt: float) → float[source]

A method to step a light sensor forwards in time. A LightSensor has no dynamics, apart from a potential delay from a DelayBlock, so technically is not integrated, but dt is passed to this method for consistency with the step methods of other classes.

Parameters:

dt (float) – Integration interval - not used here.

Returns:

The activation (level of stimulation) of the sensor. When the sensor detects multiple light sources, their effects are summed linearly.

Return type:

float

HeadingSensor class

class Sandbox_V1_4.HeadingSensor(agent, noisemaker=None, name_str: str = 'HeadingSensor', delay_steps: float = 0)[source]

A class for detecting the current heading of an Agent. For many agents, this will be the same angle as theta, the orientation of the agent, but this will not always be the case. E.g. a Bee can face in one direction and fly in another, so for the bee, heading is the direction of flight, which is not the same angle as theta.

  • delay_steps (int) – The number of simulation steps a sensor signal will be delayed for.

  • history of sensor outputs (activations): data["activations"]

FloorPatchSensor class

class Sandbox_V1_4.FloorPatchSensor(floor_patches: List[FloorPatch], x: float, y: float, noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, label: str = None, enabled: bool = True, name_str: str = 'FloorPatchSensor', delay_steps: float = 0)[source]

A class which represents a sensor for detecting coloured patches on the floor. Can detect both FloorPatch and CircularFloorPatch objects.

__init__(self, floor_patches: List[FloorPatch], x: float, y: float, noisemaker: NoiseSource = None, label: str = None, enabled: bool = True, name_str: str = 'FloorPatchSensor', delay_steps: float = 0)[source]
Parameters:

  • floor_patches (list[FloorPatch]) – The list of instances of FloorPatch which the sensor can potentially detect.

  • label (str) – A FloorPatchSensor’s label determines which of the FloorPatch s in its list it can actually detect. Defaults to None, in which case the sensor will detect all floor patches in its list. If a sensor’s label attribute is set to some string, then it will only detect floor patches which have their label attributes set to the same value.

  • x (float) – The initial x-coordinate of the FloorPatchSensor.

  • y (float) – The initial y-coordinate of the FloorPatchSensor.

  • noisemaker (NoiseSource) – The sensor’s source of noise.

  • name_str (str) – The name of the sensor, used in plotting simulation data.

  • delay_steps (int) – The number of simulation steps a sensor signal will be delayed for.

  • enabled (bool) – A flag for specifying whether or not a floor patch is enabled. Defaults to True. If set to False, then the sensor will not detect anything.

get_data() → dict[source]

A function to get the data from an FloorPatchSensor, in the form of a string-keyed dict.

These data, as and when they are included in the returned dict, can be accessed with the following keys:

  • data inherited from Sensor: see Sensor

  • current sensor output (activation): data["activation"]

  • history of sensor outputs (activations): data["activations"]

  • label of floor patches which this sensor will detect, if they are also in its list of patches: data["label"]. If this value is None, then the sensor will detect patches with any label.

  • list of floor patches that the sensor will detect, if they have the same label as it, or its label is None: data["light_sources"]

  • data of sensor’s noise source, if it has one: data["noises"]

Returns:

The sensors’s data.

Return type:

dict

reset() → None[source]

A method to reset the sensor to its initial state, so that it can be reused in a later simulation.

step(dt: float) → float[source]

A method to step a floor patch sensor forwards in time. A FloorPatchSensor has no dynamics, so technically is not stepped in time, but ‘step’ is used for consistency.

Parameters:

dt (float) – Integration interval - not used here.

Returns:

The activation (level of stimulation) of the sensor, which will be 0 when no patches are detected. When the sensor detects multiple floor patches, their effects are not summed - the output will only be 1.

Return type:

float

Radio class

class Sandbox_V1_4.Radio(x, y, transmitter_range, receiver_range, radios=[], enabled: bool = True)[source]

A class to implement a simple 2-way radio. A radio constantly transmits its message. It only receives messages from other radios which are within its own radios list. It has separate parameters for the range of its transmitter and of its receiver. Because this radio implements both transmitter and receiver, it appears under both actuators and sensors in this documentation.

__init__(self, x, y, transmitter_range, receiver_range, radios=[], enabled: bool = True)[source]
Parameters:

  • x (float) – The radio’s x-coordinate. If the radio is attached to a robot (as in Fauxkilobot), then it’s position will track that of the robot.

  • y (float) – The radio’s y-coordinate. If the radio is attached to a robot (as in Fauxkilobot), then it’s position will track that of the robot.

  • transmitter_range (float) – Only radios within transmitter_range of this radio will possibly receive its message.

  • receiver_range (float) – This radio will only possibly receive the transmission of radios within receiver_range of it.

  • radios (list(Radio)) – The list of radios which this one can potentially receive messages from. Defaults to [] - it will normally be more convenient to add radios to this list after construction, using the add_radio() method. For example, if you have \(n\) agents which you want to all communicate with each other, it is probably going to be easiest to construct all of the robots first, and then subsequently connect all of their radios.

  • enabled (bool) – A flag which can potentially be used to disable a radio. Not used in the current implementation, but will be in future.

add_radio(radio)[source]

Add a radio to the list of radios that this one can potentially communicate with.

Parameters:

radio (Radio) – The radio to add to the list.

get_data()[source]

A function to get a radios’s data.

These data, as and when they are included in the returned dict, can be accessed with the following keys:

  • enabled state: data["enabled"]

  • list of radios that this radio can potentially receive messages from: data["radios"]

  • message that this radio is transmitting: data["message"]

  • list of messages received in the last simulation step: data["received_messages"]

  • transmitter range: data["transmitter_range"]

  • receiver range: data["receiver_range"]

receive_messages()[source]

Receive messages from any in-range radios which this one can potentially communicate with.
